Combining DP Targets with the MSD

combining-with-msd.Rmd

Introduction

This vignette provides an overview for utilizing your tame_dp() output by combining them with previous targets from the MER Structured Dataset (MSD).

Setup

If you haven’t installed R or tameDP, you should first refer to the Setup vignette or if you want to know more about the options for tame_dp(), see Extracting Targets.

In addition to loading tameDP, we’re also going to need to install/load a couple others. We’ll be working with some of the other packages we installed as dependencies for tameDP, but we will need to use two other packages: here and another custom OHA package called gophr. Let’s install bothS now.

install.packages("here")
remotes::install_github("USAID-OHA-SI/gophr", build_vignettes = TRUE)

Alright, with gophr installed to work with the MSD, let’s get going.

library(tameDP)
library(gophr)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(here)

The first step is reading in the from the Data Pack target. We are going to work with the targets out the target tabs, assuming the PSNUxIM is not yet populated. Remember, Windows filepaths have their slash in the wrong direction. You will need to replace all backslashes (“/") in your filepath with forward slashes (”/“).

#data pack file path
dp_filepath <- here("tools/DataPack_Jupiter_20500101.xlsx")
#process the data pack to extract the targets
df_dp <- tame_dp(dp_filepath)

#glimpse the output
df_dp %>% 
  select(-psnuuid) %>% 
  glimpse()
#> Rows: 21,709
#> Columns: 14
#> $ operatingunit            <chr> "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "~
#> $ countryname              <chr> "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "~
#> $ snu1                     <chr> "_Military Jupiter", "_Military Jupiter", "_M~
#> $ psnu                     <chr> "_Military Jupiter", "_Military Jupiter", "_M~
#> $ fiscal_year              <dbl> 2050, 2050, 2050, 2050, 2050, 2050, 2050, 205~
#> $ indicator                <chr> "HTS_INDEX", "HTS_INDEX", "HTS_INDEX", "HTS_I~
#> $ standardizeddisaggregate <chr> "Age/Sex/Result", "Age/Sex/Result", "Age/Sex/~
#> $ numeratordenom           <chr> "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", ~
#> $ ageasentered             <chr> "10-14", "10-14", "15-19", "15-19", "20-24", ~
#> $ sex                      <chr> "Female", "Male", "Female", "Male", "Female",~
#> $ modality                 <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N~
#> $ statushiv                <chr> "Negative", "Negative", "Negative", "Negative~
#> $ otherdisaggregate        <chr> "NewNeg", "NewNeg", "NewNeg", "NewNeg", "NewN~
#> $ targets                  <dbl> 34, 40, 32, 44, 44, 100, 92, 176, 148, 224, 2~

We now have all the targets extracted from the Data Pack and stored in a tidy dataframe called df_dp. We want to combine this with the MSD. You will need to download your country’s MSD from PEPFAR Panorama. For our analysis, let’s look across PSNUs so we will want to download the PSNUxIM dataset. Once you have it downloaded, you will want to use gophr::read_msd() to open the MSD.

#msd file path
dp_filepath <- here("../../../Downloads/MER_Structured_Datasets_PSNU_IM_FY45-49_Jupiter.txt")

#read in MSD
df_msd <- read_msd(dp_filepath)

The PSNUxIM file has a few more columns that we need.

#extra column names in the MSD
setdiff(names(df_msd), names(df_dp))
#>  [1] "operatingunituid"         "snu1uid"                 
#>  [3] "snuprioritization"        "typemilitary"            
#>  [5] "dreams"                   "primepartner"            
#>  [7] "fundingagency"            "mech_code"               
#>  [9] "mech_name"                "pre_rgnlztn_hq_mech_code"
#> [11] "prime_partner_duns"       "award_number"            
#> [13] "indicatortype"            "disaggregate"            
#> [15] "categoryoptioncomboname"  "trendsfine"              
#> [17] "trendssemifine"           "trendscoarse"            
#> [19] "statustb"                 "statuscx"                
#> [21] "hiv_treatment_status"     "otherdisaggregate_sub"   
#> [23] "qtr1"                     "qtr2"                    
#> [25] "qtr3"                     "qtr4"                    
#> [27] "cumulative"               "source_name"

#no exta columns in the Data Pack
setdiff(names(df_dp), names(df_msd))
#> character(0)

It also has more indicators and disaggregates that aren’t in the Data Pack. To simplify matters, we can subset, or limit, the dataset to what we have to work with. Luckily we have a table stored in this packaged called mer_disagg_mapping that contains all the indicators and their disaggregates that we can use to filter the MSD by.

mer_disagg_mapping
#> # A tibble: 60 x 4
#>    indicator        numeratordenom standardizeddisaggregate      kp_disagg
#>    <chr>            <chr>          <chr>                         <lgl>    
#>  1 AGYW_PREV        D              Age/Sex/DREAMSBegun           FALSE    
#>  2 AGYW_PREV        N              Age/Sex/DREAMSPrimaryComplete FALSE    
#>  3 CXCA_SCRN        N              Age/Sex/HIVStatus             FALSE    
#>  4 DIAGNOSED_SUBNAT N              Age/Sex/HIVStatus             FALSE    
#>  5 GEND_GBV         N              ViolenceServiceType           FALSE    
#>  6 HIV_PREV         N              Age/Sex                       FALSE    
#>  7 HTS_INDEX_COM    N              Age/Sex/Result                FALSE    
#>  8 HTS_INDEX_FAC    N              Age/Sex/Result                FALSE    
#>  9 HTS_RECENT       N              KeyPop/HIVStatus              TRUE     
#> 10 HTS_RECENT       N              Modality/Age/Sex/HIVStatus    FALSE    
#> # ... with 50 more rows

Combining the names from our Data Pack data frame (names(df_dp)) to limit the columns and using an inner join to keep only the target disaggregates, we can then append or bind this with onto the MSD data frame.

#subset data from MSD
df_msd_lim <- df_msd %>% 
  select(all_of(names(df_dp))) %>% 
  inner_join(mer_disagg_mapping, by = c("indicator", "standardizeddisaggregate", "numeratordenom"))

#bind Data Pack data onto MSD
df_msd_dp <- df_msd_lim %>% 
  bind_rows(df_dp) %>% 
  select(-psnuuid) %>% 
  glimpse()
#> Rows: 176,953
#> Columns: 15
#> $ operatingunit            <chr> "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "~
#> $ countryname              <chr> "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "Jupiter", "~
#> $ snu1                     <chr> "East", "North", "East", "_Military Jupiter",~
#> $ psnu                     <chr> "Gemini", "Orion", "Scorpius", "_Military Jup~
#> $ fiscal_year              <dbl> 2048, 2048, 2047, 2049, 2047, 2047, 2047, 204~
#> $ indicator                <chr> "TX_PVLS", "HTS_TST", "HTS_TST_POS", "HTS_TST~
#> $ standardizeddisaggregate <chr> "Age/Sex/Indication/HIVStatus", "Modality/Age~
#> $ numeratordenom           <chr> "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", "N", ~
#> $ ageasentered             <chr> "10-14", "50+", "45-49", "35-39", "40-49", "3~
#> $ sex                      <chr> "Female", "Male", "Female", "Male", "Female",~
#> $ modality                 <chr> NA, "STI Clinic", "PMTCT ANC", "STI Clinic", ~
#> $ statushiv                <chr> "Positive", "Negative", "Positive", "Negative~
#> $ otherdisaggregate        <chr> "Targeted", NA, "Newly Identified", NA, NA, N~
#> $ targets                  <dbl> NA, 17, NA, 90, 4, 742, 1, 5, NA, 3, 140, 14,~
#> $ kp_disagg                <lgl> FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FAL~

We now have a joined data frame that we can use to compare indicator trends over time. For instance, we can compare how this year’s TX_NEW targets compare with previous few years’ targets across ages.

df_tx_trend <- df_msd_dp %>% 
  filter(indicator == "TX_NEW",
         standardizeddisaggregate == "Age/Sex/HIVStatus") %>% 
  count(fiscal_year, indicator, ageasentered, wt = targets, name = "targets")

Finally, we can reshape the data to get it into an easy table to view the trends.

df_tx_trend %>%
  filter(fiscal_year >= 2048) %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = fiscal_year,
              values_from = targets)
#> # A tibble: 13 x 5
#>    indicator ageasentered `2048` `2049` `2050`
#>    <chr>     <chr>         <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>
#>  1 TX_NEW    <01             254     75    515
#>  2 TX_NEW    01-04          1152    137    128
#>  3 TX_NEW    05-09          1202     63   1065
#>  4 TX_NEW    10-14          1975    968   2291
#>  5 TX_NEW    15-19          3861   3346   5047
#>  6 TX_NEW    20-24          6181   5294   8937
#>  7 TX_NEW    25-29          6774   6077  11740
#>  8 TX_NEW    30-34          9973   5751  12770
#>  9 TX_NEW    35-39          5754   2781  11401
#> 10 TX_NEW    40-44          5280   3848   6987
#> 11 TX_NEW    45-49          4614   3231   3352
#> 12 TX_NEW    50+            7344   8045   3680
#> 13 TX_NEW    Unknown Age       0      0     NA
